abstracts.cdata!:
The Bangladesh Water Supply Program
            Projects is a pilot initiative, whose overall focus is based
            on three guiding principles that will 1) assist the
            Government in moving forward towards achieving the
            Millennium Development Goals for water supply and sanitation
            by 2015; 2) scale up measures to provide arsenic free, and
            bacteriological safe water in rural areas, and small towns;
            and, 3) support the decentralization process initiated by
            the Government as part of the water sector reform process.
            This environmental assessment (EA) provides an insight into
            the  challenges in  dealing with water quality problems, and
            those related to management of surface and ground water. The
            EA outlines several types of risks: capacity building risks
            of different institutions likely to be involved in the
            project, enforcement and contractual risks for private
            sector participation, tariff rationalization risks, policy
            reform risks, environmental risks and risk of coordination
            among the different stakeholders for a better operational
            strategy. It suggests  mitigation strategies, and a
            monitoring plan as follows. The monitoring plan includes an
            environmental checklist for both rural and urban areas that
            can be used as a tool to assess the status of adverse
            impacts during project implementation. Adverse environmental
            impacts include shallow and deep aquifers, treated dug/ring
            wells, piped water supply schemes from treated surface water
            sources, rainwater harvesting, pond-sand filter, arsenic
            removal units attached to the contaminated tubewells, and
            domestic filter at the household level. Other possible
            impacts on natural habitat, and other pollution include
            traffic congestion, noise pollution and drainage problems.
            The environmental management strategy gives special emphasis
            on arsenic contamination: its health implications, arsenic
            removal technologies, water quality surveillance, and
            arsenic sludge disposal options, and, further indicates the
            relevant environmental legislations that can be used during
            implementation. It also provides a rapid environmental
            assessment checklist that can be used for both rural and
            urban water supply projects.
